p: NidamJS is a framework-agnostic JavaScript library designed to inject desktop-like logic into web frontends. It enables windows, taskbar, icons, and related UI/UX features without requiring backend changes.
Window Management: Full window lifecycle (open, close, minimize, maximize).
Desktop Experience: Taskbar, desktop icons, and context menus.
Framework Agnostic: Works with React, Vue, Svelte, Angular, or Vanilla JS.
Get up and running in seconds.
Learn about the architecture and modules.
Detailed docs on Windows, Taskbar, and Icons.
NidamJS is released under the MIT License.
Get started with NidamJS by adding it to your project. You can install it via your favorite package manager or include it directly via CDN.
Install NidamJS using npm, yarn or bun.
If you prefer not to use a package manager, you can include NidamJS directly in your HTML file via a CDN like unpkg or jsDelivr.
Now that you have installed NidamJS, head over to the Quick Start guide to create your first desktop-like environment.
Get your first NidamJS desktop environment running in minutes.
Create an HTML file and add a container element where the windows will be rendered. You also need to define a taskbar if you want application management.
Import createNidamApp from the library and initialize it pointing to your target container.
NidamJS works with endpoints. An endpoint can be a URL that returns window HTML, or a reference to a local template.
For static sites, you can define windows inside template tags with a data-route.
Then open it using the route name:

Icons are the primary interactive elements of the NidamJS desktop. They represent applications, files, or system actions. The system uses a declarative, attribute-based grid that handles positioning, drag-and-drop, and layout persistence automatically.
To create a functional desktop icon grid, wrap your icons in a container using the nd-icons attribute.
The icon system is controlled via three main nd- attributes. You generally do not need to write JavaScript to manage these; the internal IconManager detects them automatically.
Applied to the parent element to define the grid dimensions.
Example: nd-icons=8:5 creates a grid with 8 columns and 5 rows.
Applied to individual icon elements to set their initial or current position.
Behavior: If a position is already occupied, the system will automatically find the nearest available spot.
Required for persistence. * Purpose: This ID is used as the key when saving the icon's position to local storage. Without an nd-id, the icon will reset to its default HTML position on page refresh.
Defines the grid size (e.g., 10:6). Sets CSS variables --nd-cols and --nd-rows.
The ID of the window/modal to trigger on click.
The X:Y coordinate of the icon. Updates dynamically after a drag.
Unique string used to save/load the position from storage.
Deadzone & Delay: A small movement "deadzone" and time delay prevent accidental drags during simple clicks.
Ghosting: While dragging, a transparent "ghost" element follows the cursor (.nd-icon-ghost), while the original icon remains dimmed (.is-dragging).
Auto-Snapping: Upon release, the icon snaps to the nearest valid grid cell.
Collision Detection: Icons cannot overlap. If you drop an icon on an occupied cell, the move is canceled.
The layout is automatically saved to localStorage under the key nd-icons-layout.
On page load, the system checks storage for coordinates matching the icon's nd-id.
If found, the nd-icon attribute is updated, and the icon is moved to its last saved position.
NidamJS icons are built with Design Tokens (CSS Variables). You can easily customize the entire desktop experience by overriding these variables in your own stylesheet.
All variables are defined under :root but can be scoped to specific [nd-icons] containers if you want different styles for different desktop areas.
Inner padding of the desktop container.
Responsive sizing of the icon image.
The background color of the icon text.
The scale factor when hovering an icon.
Transparency of the icon following the mouse.
Transparency of the original icon during drag.
The system automatically adapts to prefers-color-scheme: dark, but you can force specific colors:
If you want a dense, small-icon grid, you can override the variables directly on the container:
While you should primarily use variables, you can target these classes for advanced CSS overrides:
.is-dragging: Added to the icon currently being moved.
.nd-icon-ghost: The temporary element created during a drag operation (appended to body).
Note: The nd-icon-ghost element is removed from the DOM as soon as the mouse is released.

The Taskbar component provides a persistent interface for launching applications and managing open windows in the NidamJS desktop environment. It displays application icons that serve as triggers to open windows, with visual feedback when windows are open.

The taskbar acts as the primary navigation hub for the desktop. It docks to one edge of the screen and displays application icons. When a window is open, the corresponding taskbar icon shows an active indicator, and clicking the icon will either bring the existing window into focus or open a new one.
The TaskbarManager class handles the taskbar functionality:
Event Binding: Listens for clicks on taskbar icons to trigger window opening
Window State Sync: Subscribes to window:opened and window:closed events to update icon states
Visual Feedback: Toggles the is-open class on icons based on window state

When you click a taskbar icon, the manager calls windowManager.open(endpoint) with the endpoint specified in the icon's data-modal attribute. If a window with that endpoint is already open, it will be brought into focus.
Flexible Positioning: Dock the taskbar to the bottom (default), left, or right side of the screen
Visual Indicators: Active applications display a pill-shaped indicator below the icon
Automatic Sync: Real-time updates based on window lifecycle events
Responsive Animations: Smooth transitions for hover states and state changes
Multiple Styles: Default floating style and extended Windows-style bar
The taskbar is defined in HTML using the nd-taskbar attribute. Individual items use the nd-taskbar-icon attribute and must map to a window endpoint via data-modal.
NidamJS provides two built-in taskbar styles:
The default floating style positions the taskbar as a rounded bar that floats above the desktop with a glassmorphic appearance.
The extended style creates a full-width bar docked to the bottom of the screen, similar to the Windows taskbar.
You can change the orientation and position of the taskbar using the nd-taskbar-position attribute.
For the extended taskbar style, you can add text labels beneath or beside icons:
The TaskbarManager targets specific attributes to apply logic and styling.
The taskbar styles are organized in three CSS files:
root.css: Defines all CSS custom properties (variables)
default.css: Implements the default floating taskbar style
extend.css: Implements the extended Windows-style taskbar
Customize the look and feel of the taskbar by overriding CSS custom properties in your stylesheet. Variables are scoped under the [nd-taskbar] selector.
When using nd-taskbar=extend, additional variables customize the Windows-style appearance:
Sets the placement of the taskbar.
The window endpoint/ID to trigger on click.
The TaskbarManager listens for these window events:
Fired when a window opens. Updates the corresponding taskbar icon to show the active indicator.
Fired when a window closes. Removes the active indicator from the corresponding taskbar icon.
To manually control taskbar icons from JavaScript:

The Window component is the primary container for application content within the NidamJS desktop environment. It mimics the behavior of a native operating system window, supporting dragging, resizing, minimizing, maximizing, and closing.
A window consists of a title bar (with controls) and a content body. It floats above the desktop background and other windows, managed by a z-index stacking context.
Draggable: Move the window around the desktop area by its title bar.
Resizable: Windows can be resized or snapped to screen edges.
Stateful: Supports maximized, tiled, and focused states.
Focus Management: Clicking a window brings it to the front and applies the .focused class.
Snapping: Windows snap to screen edges (top, left, right) for easy multitasking.
Windows are typically served as HTML strings (e.g., from an endpoint or a template). They must contain the .window class and a draggable bar with the data-bar attribute.
Use the windowManager.open() method or the data-modal attribute on a trigger element.
Added when the window fills the screen.
NidamJS uses the following classes and attributes for window management.
The draggable area (usually the title bar).
The root container for a window.
You can customize how windows appear and disappear:
When initializing createNidamApp, you can configure the window manager:
Set to maximize, left, or right for initial placement.
(Internal) The unique identifier for the window.
Triggered when a window is added to the DOM.
Triggered when a window starts closing.
Common patterns for building with NidamJS.
The most common way to open a window is via a button in your HTML.
Since windows are fetched as HTML, you usually handle data on the server. However, you can use window:opened to inject data after loading.
NidamJS handles the ESC key by default, but you can trigger it manually.
Initialize third-party libraries inside a window after it opens.
Use the registry to automatically bind logic to specific elements whenever a new window is opened.
NidamJS is configured by passing an object to createNidamApp(). This object controls global behavior, window manager settings, and module adapters.
Delay in ms before a refresh or destructive closure.
List of feature modules to auto-initialize in new content.
Selector for the element where windows are appended.
These options control the overall environment setup.
Configure the core physics and lifecycle of windows under the windowManager.config key.
Height reserved for the taskbar (affects maximize/snap).
How long to auto-recenter windows after initial load.
Maximum number of concurrent open windows.
Minimum time between opening the same window.
Pixels to move before a drag operation starts.
The starting z-index for the window stack.
You can override default behaviors by providing functions under windowManager.
Windows are the fundamental building blocks of the NidamJS desktop environment. Unlike traditional components that take a data object, NidamJS windows are defined as HTML endpoints.
To open a window, use the open() method on the window module.
NidamJS supports two ways to load content:
Network Fetch: If static mode is disabled (default), NidamJS fetches the endpoint URL. It adds the header X-Modal-Request: 1.
Static Templates: If static: true is set in the Window Manager config, NidamJS looks for a template data-route=endpoint element in the document.
For a window to be managed by NidamJS (draggable, closable), it must have a specific structure in its HTML response.
The outermost container. Must be present.
The element the user clicks to drag the window.
Any element that should close the window on click.
Any element that should maximize the window on click.
You can listen for window events on the root document.
Once you have a reference to a window element, you can use the Window Manager methods:

NidamJS is a modular system that overlays a desktop environment onto standard web pages. It uses event delegation and runtime injection to manage windows and taskbars without a heavy framework lock-in.
NidamJS consists of a central NidamApp instance that orchestrates several Managers.
Initializes the Event Delegator for global click/drag handling.
Spawns and stores manager modules (window, taskbar, refresher).
Runs the Content Initializer to wire up features in newly fetched HTML.
WindowManager: The heart of the library. It handles the lifecycle (fetch, open, close) and physics (dragging, snapping, tiling) of windows.
TaskbarManager: Syncs with the WindowManager to show which windows are open and provides visual feedback via the is-open class.
WindowRefresher: Listens for server-emitted events to automatically refresh the content of specific windows or close windows whose underlying data has been deleted.
DesktopIconManager: (Optional) Manages the grid layout and persistence of shortcuts on the background layer.
Unlike component-based frameworks, NidamJS relies on a DOM Contract.
When you call windowManager.open('profile'), the library:
Fetches the HTML from the endpoint.
Parses the HTML looking for an element with the .window class.
Appends that element to the modalContainer.
Initializes all behaviors (dragging, closing) based on data- attributes.
This allows you to serve window content from any backend (PHP, Python, Node) or static HTML templates.
NidamJS uses standard DOM events for communication.
window:opened: Fired when a window is added to the DOM and initialized.
window:closed: Fired when a window is removed from the DOM.

The EventDelegator listens for clicks on the document. When it sees an element with data-modal=xyz, it automatically tells the WindowManager to open that endpoint. You don't need to write onclick handlers for most basic triggers.

Windows are stacked dynamically. Whenever a window is clicked or opened, its z-index is incremented to be higher than the current maximum, ensuring it appears on top. The base z-index can be configured via zIndexBase.
This section provides technical details for the NidamJS public API classes, methods, and properties.
Configuration and adapters for the Window Manager.
CSS selector for the element that will contain windows.
List of feature definitions for automatic initialization.
NidamApp: An instance of the application.
The primary factory function used to initialize the NidamJS environment.
The NidamApp instance manages the lifecycle of different modules.
Starts event delegation and initializes all managers. Must be called once.
Returns the internal Map containing all active modules.
Accessible via app.getModule('window'). Manages window lifecycle and interaction.
Opens a window for a given endpoint.
endpoint (string): The URL or template route to load.
force (boolean): If true, bypasses cooldowns and creates a new instance even if one exists.
Closes a specific window element with animation.
Brings a window to the foreground.
Toggles between maximized and restored states.
NidamJS windows are plain HTMLElements that must follow a specific internal structure.
The draggable handle (usually the title bar).
(Internal) The unique ID assigned to the window.
The TaskbarManager primarily operates through event listeners and DOM attributes (nd-taskbar, tb-icon). It does not currently expose a public method API for dynamic item management.
If initialized manually or via registry:
The DesktopIconManager handles drag-and-drop persistence for desktop icons. It targets elements with the .desktop-icon class.
Optional prefix for the storage key.
